awd_titl_txt: Conduits and Control of KatG Intramolecular Electron Transfer: Formation and Operation of a Novel Cofactor
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is jointly funded by the Molecular Biophysics Cluster in the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences and the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Division of Chemistry.

This project investigates an enzyme (KatG) at the center of the chemical warfare that rages between pathogenic microorganisms and their plant/animal hosts. Hosts produce hydrogen peroxide as part of an elaborate microbial killing system, and many pathogens produce this enzyme to defend themselves. KatG-producing pathogens range from the rice-blast fungus, which annually costs billions of dollars in crop losses, to tuberculosis, which kills millions of people each year. Clearly, it is important to understand how KatG works. Such knowledge may provide a foundation for future interventions that make these pathogens more susceptible to their hosts' own defenses. This project provides research training for graduate and undergraduate students. Most importantly, it contributes to increasing success of at-risk students from underrepresented groups, minimizing their attrition from STEM majors and maximizing the likelihood they will complete their degrees. Finally, this research helps generate new STEM learning opportunities for Alabama prisoners by contributing material that excites interest and engages future participation of prisoners in STEM learning. 

Intramolecular electron transfer is central to all aspects of KatG catalysis, including formation of its methionine-tyrosine-tryptophan (MYW) cofactor, the use of the cofactor for catalysis, the accumulation of inactive intermediates, and return of those intermediates to activity by exogenous electron donors. However, the intermediates of these processes and their mechanisms of control are poorly defined. To address these unknowns, this project is divided into two parts. The first evaluates KatG already containing its MYW cofactor, and the second evaluates KatG prior to cofactor formation. The former will elucidate the intermediates necessary for active catalysis as well as those that lead to inactivation, whereas the latter will address the intermediates that lead to and detract from de novo MYW cofactor synthesis. In both cases, the mechanisms by which the KatG protein itself controls the routes of electron transfer will be addressed, as will the ability of exogenous electron donors to restore inactive intermediates. As such, a broad suite of paired kinetic and spectroscopic methods, from chemical-quench peptide mapping to freeze-quench Mossbauer spectroscopy, will be applied to KatG variants targeting the proximal tryptophan and/or the arginine switch.

Intellectual Merit

Higher eukaryotes, from plants to humans, generate large quantities of hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) as a key component of their defense against invading bacterial and fungal pathogens. Although H2O2 is itself toxic, its antimicrobial value is greatly enhanced when it is used to generate far more destructive compounds against which there is little if any defense (e.g, hypochlorite from activated neutrophils). As such, pathogens must be able to deploy robust systems for the rapid and sustained degradation of H2O2. A wide range of notorious pathogens (e.g., Mycobacterium tuberculosis) rely on the enzyme KatG for H2O2 degradation.

This project has uncovered the seamless integration of four structural features of KatG which are indispensable to its remarkable peroxide-degrading capacity: 1) highly restricted active-site access, 2) a composition extraordinarily rich in oxidizable amino acids, especially tryptophan, tyrosine, and methionine, one of each of which has been used to produce 3) a covalently linked methionine-tyrosine-tryptophan (MYW) protein-based cofactor, and 4) a conformationally dynamic arginine. Together, these features enable KatG to degrade H2O2 over a wide range of conditions and far in excess of any other member of its superfamily.

This project has highlighted the common theme that underlies all aspects of KatG catalysis and unifies them into a cohesive model for H2O2 decomposition: intramolecular electron transfer (electron transfers within KatG?s structure). Mature (i.e., MYW-bearing) KatG displays two sets of protein-based radicals generated through intra-protein electron transfer reactions. One is the MYW.+ which is invariably associated with the direct reactions of KatG's catalase mechanism, and the second is a group of protein-based radicals from off-catalase electron transfers, or electron transfers outside the catalase mechanism.  At first, these two appear to be at odds with one another, but this project has shown that the latter is an elaborate fail-safe mechanism that permits KatG to consume 10x more H2O2 than it would otherwise be able to do. A highly restrictive active-site access channel combined with a highly oxidizable protein structure ensures that KatG's interaction with exogenous electron donors does not interfere with but only sustains degradation of H2O2 through the enzyme's catalase activity. The arginine switch, whose conformation is influenced by pH, is a regulator between catalase and off-catalase electron transfers. KatG, lacking either its arginine switch or key oxidizable amino acids (e.g., tryptophan 321), shows a substantial decrease in ability to dispose of H2O2 by catalase activity, but these effects are limited to specific conditions (e.g., low pH). However, KatG lacking both features is profoundly sensitive to peroxide-based inactivation across a broad range of conditions.

The MYW cofactor enables catalase activity in an active site which would otherwise only act as a peroxidase. The generation of MYW from its component side chains is proposed to arise from intramolecular electron transfers and protein radical-based reactions. Using tools developed here (see below), MYW formation was monitored in real time. Though the overall reaction requires peroxide, the rate-determining step (k = 0.2 s-1) is peroxide-concentration independent. Formation of MYW appeared to be preceded first by peroxide-dependent formation of a FeIV=O[porphyrin].+ intermediate followed by a transition to FeIV=O[protein].+, and the first protein-based radicals putatively connected with cofactor formation were observed. Interestingly, the arginine switch and oxidizable residues near the active site have little influence on MYW formation.

Broader Impact

The Goodwin laboratory developed protocols that not only advanced this project but may also be utilized by investigators in this and other fields. A simple and robust heme reconstitution procedure enabled production of KatG primed to form its MYW cofactor upon exposure to peroxide. It was successfully used across multiple KatG variants and enabled direct comparison to enzyme already bearing MYW. Combined with a new pre-steady-state protocol, the establishment of the cofactor was observed in real time. An assay to monitor KatG inactivation in real time was developed as was a procedure to quantify the factors that influence resistance to peroxide-dependent inactivation.

This project made significant contributions to a stronger and more diverse scientific workforce through the training of 13 students. Every student involved has advanced toward their STEM career goals. Of five graduate students (all of whom are women), three completed PhDs and secured postdocs; two advanced to PhD candidacy and will complete their degrees within one year. Of eight undergraduates, two are now in PhD programs, two are in medical school, and a fifth is pursuing her MPH. Upon graduation, three others will pursue an MD, an MD/PhD, and a Chemistry PhD. Six of the eight undergraduates are women, three of whom are African-American. Finally, this project aided the delivery of science education to learners incarcerated in the Alabama Department of Corrections (ADOC). Ideas and materials generated through this research informed lecture demonstrations and materials on structural biology, free-radical biochemistry, and enzymology that were prepared and delivered by the PI within multiple ADOC facilities.
